Award.AwardTitle: Access to the Gig Economy: Infrastructural Competence and the Participation of Underrepresented Populations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research advances our understanding of how people from disadvantaged backgrounds pursue work in the the so-called knowledge-based gig economy, doing contract work such as programming and writing. The research will delve into how these workers obtain, assemble, and organize digital resources, such as mobile devices, software and services, storage, security, and interconnectivity, to accomplish their jobs. These workers, especially if they lack an office, may work in coffee shops, libraries, co-working centers, and other on-the-go places. Some have routine circuits of travel and can rely on co-working spaces; some are more nomadic. Either way, they must organize and reconfigure their work resources, creating "mobile offices" that provide cognitive space (attention), physical space (room to work), communications (relationships with others), and direct work resources. Digital technologies are usually necessary and require technical and social competence and financial resources. Recent studies show that this kind of work is likely to become a larger part of the future workforce.

One goal of this research is to understand in greater depth what will be needed to make this kind of work successful, and to identify the particular challenges and needs of workers who come from disadvantaged backgrounds (such as single parents, rural workers, etc). A second goal of this work is to develop better methods for collecting data on contract or gig workers, and how to understand the alternative uses of these workers' digital platforms, applications, and devices. It is probable that unobtrusive data collection about application uses, connections, and access to digital resources will be needed to complement current field-based data collection methods. Data collection will focus on the ways in which disadvantaged workers create their digital collections and pursue work. The research will also involve integrating data collected unobtrusively. This project will employ graduate students who themselves come from disadvantaged backgrounds to contribute to their development and to gain from their perspectives. The research will contribute to our expectations for training and preparation of a digitally-enabled workforce of the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research focused on the opportunities for contemporary workers from economically-disadvantaged backgrounds to participate in knowledge-driven, often online, labor markets (e.g., the ‘gig’ economy or contract-, not employment-, based work).  We know that many of these workers pursue their labor in ways that are distinct and different from traditional office workers, who are often tied to specific, if not single, locales and often for a sole employer.  Workers from these communities bring different forms of (and often less) formal education, limited language skills (for many immigrants and refugees), and less enculturation to the open labor markets and confusing legal arrangements of the contemporary US workforce. So, we used detailed field work to assess how workers gained access to the knowledge-based work that is often heralded as the engine of a digital economy.

    We come away from this work with five insights.  The first insight is that the workers from economically-disadvantaged situations and communities have a difficult time securing online knowledge work.  Their educational experience is hard for employers to assess. And, these worker’s language skills further diminish their chances of securing work. These deficits are often magnified by their reliance on mobile phones and spotty internet access as the only means to engaged the digital world.  The limits imposed by this constrained access on their digital skills and/or jobs platform skills is a second magnifier of difficulty. Finally, we observe that even the most ambitious of those seeking online/gig work have little guidance from within their own social worlds to help them succeed – much less get started – in this different space.

   The second insight is the reliance on informal work and bartering among peers and others in their social worlds for work. many of the workers pursue important-to-their-community knowledge work. That is, they help others by filling out and tracking the many local, state and Federal forms that are needed to secure resource, move towards citizenship, find places to live, establish residency, etc. For those coming from non-native-English-speaking countries or heritages, they are doing interpretation. These workers serve as informational guide-posts for their communities. Often with limited pay, these workers play critical and central roles in their communities. Identifying and supporting these roles seems a spectacular public-policy opportunity.

   The third insight we take from this work is that our original intent was misguided. We were motivated to understand how our neighbors, friend and fellow citizens – many of them new Americans or from communities faced with sustained economic hardship – were working to adapt to the open and amorphous labor markets that they face: online work via third-party vendors (like care.com, fivver and taskrabbit), hourly work in service industries – often without benefits or control on hours; and, informal labor. What we found was these communities support their own informal labor markets, working in and across community borders and spaces where they could develop trust-based and reciprocal arrangements. These communities are learning to leverage the hodgepodge of resources from private organization, well-meaning individuals and public (at local, state and Federal levels) institutions. That is, a substantial amount of the talent and knowledge within these communities are being directed at navigating the resources and sustaining the networks, families and communities. 

   The fourth insight we draw from our work is the attention paid to ensuring the children of these communities gain educational opportunities. This is more clearly seen within some immigrant communities. But, it is visible across all those with whom we studied. For all the reasons above, the parents, elders and community activists, social workers, economic development aid, and siblings see education as the path to better jobs, more income and stability.  That so many of the current generation who are now entering contemporary labor markets find this problematic is an alarm for our future.

    Finally, our work was challenged by access and this learning and efforts to redress the issue substantially delayed the project. Having worked in and around many of these communities for years (as a parent, volunteer and neighbor), our initial approach was premised on pre-existing pathways of access. This was not the case. We had to recruit, train, and then re-develop ties into these communities: something that took two or more years to accomplish.  What we found challenged the public-policy rhetoric, the workplace discussions and the educational enthusiasms that seem so comforting to those who stand outside these communities.  We come out of the field chagrined by our ignorance, challenged by what we have learned, and eager to see a larger and more sustained effort to support education, community-building and access to work for the citizens and new Americans that reside in economically-disadvantaged communities and locations: online labor markets are not readily available and not of great value.
